title.narrative: ERW risk mitigation through clearance and risk education in Gaza

description.narrative:
During the Operation "Guardian of the Walls", an estimated 258 buildings, comprising 1,042 housing and commercial units in Gaza were destroyed and 769 units have been severely damaged, rendered uninhabitable (MoH, 20 May 2021). UNICEF estimates that 57 education facilities and 29 health facilities in the Gaza Strip suffered damage as a result of the intense hostilities. The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) launched an estimated 4,223 strikes via air, sea and land (United Nations Department of Security Services - UNDSS, 20 May 2021). A sizable proportion of the items discharged did not explode on impact, the estimated failure rate is 10%, meaning the conflict has left a dangerous explosive legacy with a large number of Explosive Remnants of War (ERW) remaining on the ground across Gaza.
Two Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) teams will be deployed to Gaza for a period of 4.5 months initially to undertake the risk assessments to confirm the presence or absence of ERW, provide details of the risk levels and to remove the risk where feasible (in UN premises). EOD teams will liaise closely with the EOD Police for clearance, enabling UN agencies and humanitarian partners to deliver humanitarian activities safely and efficiently. UNMAS Palestine will initially focus on Designated Emergency Shelters (DES) and UNRWA schools which are being used as informal shelters as well as medical facilities and will be guided by the priorities of the inter-agency Emergency Coordination Committee (ECC) and UNRWA.
While the risk assessments are ongoing, civilians and aid workers alike must be equipped with the knowledge to recognize and mitigate explosive risk in their vicinity. UNMAS Palestine will continue its provision of Explosive Ordnance Risk Education (EORE) to UN and humanitarian staff. Tailored EORE and Conflict Preparedness and Protection (CPP) will also be delivered to internally displaced persons, teachers and civilians in high-risk areas. UNMAS Palestine will increase its reach to ensure that all vulnerable people in Gaza receive awareness messages through SMS, radio messages, TV messages and leaflets and posters at all DES. Messaging will be gender responsive and will be constantly updated to reflect the findings of the ongoing assessments, so that civilians are aware of the specific devices and explosive hazards in their vicinity.
The project targets a total of 6,200 affected people with Protection - Mine Action activities.
